[[File:Mini-Sniffer II in Flight.jpg|thumb|The [[NASA Mini-Sniffer]] was considered as a Mars airplane in the 1970s, and a version that ran on hydrazine was also developed<ref name="nasa.gov">{{Cite web | url=http://www.nasa.gov/centers/dryden/multimedia/imagegallery/Mini-Sniffer/Mini-Sniffer_proj_desc.html | title=Mini-Sniffer| date=2015-09-28}}</ref>]] [[File:MarsRoverHelicopter-20150122.png|thumb|A planned [[Mars Helicopter]], to scout routes for rovers<ref>{{Cite web | url=http://mars.jpl.nasa.gov/msl/multimedia/images/?ImageID=6939 | title=Helicopter Could be 'Scout' for Mars Rovers - Mars Science Laboratory}}</ref>]] A '''Mars aircraft''' is a vehicle for flying in the atmosphere of [[Mars]]. So far, Mars lander entry, descent, and landing systems have passed through the atmosphere. Aircraft may provide ''[[in situ]]'' measurements of the [[atmosphere of Mars]], as well as additional observations over extended areas. A long-term goal is to develop piloted Mars aircraft.<ref>[https://archive.today/20120717061237/http://www.airspacemag.com/space-exploration/mars.html?c=y&page=1 Oliver Morton – '''MarsAir''' (January 2000) – Air & Space magazine]</ref><ref name=morton/>
Compared to Earth, the air is thinner at the surface (with pressure less than 1% of Earth's at sea level) but the gravity is lower (less than 40%).<ref name=uk1/><ref name=morton/> Mars air, consisting mostly of {{chem|C|O|2}} gas, is over 50% denser than Earth air adjusted to equal pressure.<ref name=morton>{{Cite web |url=http://quest.nasa.gov/aero/planetary/MarsAir.html |title=Oliver Morton – MarsAir How to build the first extraterrestrial airplane. – NASA Quest |access-date=2012-05-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111218204304/http://quest.nasa.gov/aero/planetary/MarsAir.html |archive-date=2011-12-18 |url-status=dead }}</ref>
==History== In 1918, the Danish science fiction film ''Himmelskibet'' (aka [[A Trip to Mars]]) included an aerospace craft called "Excelsior" for a manned trip to Mars.<ref>[https://io9.gizmodo.com/coolest-and-weirdest-spaceship-designs-from-before-the-1149643865]</ref>
Before the start of Mars exploration with spacecraft, the density of Mars' atmosphere was suspected to be higher than was later measured to be, leading engineers to think that winged flight would be much easier than it actually is. In his "[[The Mars Project|Mars Project]]" ("Das Marsproject") concept,<ref>{{cite book | last = von Braun | first = Wernher | authorlink = Wernher von Braun | title = The Mars Project | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=V16e-xQmyZQC | year = 1991 | origyear= 1952 | edition = 2nd | publisher = [[University of Illinois Press]] | isbn = 978-0-252-06227-8}}</ref> [[Wernher von Braun]] proposed winged vehicles for landing human missions on Mars.<ref name=morton/>
The first detailed Mars lander contracted by NASA was to Ford/Philco [[Aeronutronic]] in the early 1960s, which was for a lifting body design for the lander; this is when some of best estimates for the Mars atmosphere were significantly denser than revealed by the [[Mariner IV]] measurements in July 1965.<ref name="The Road to Mars">{{Cite news|url=https://www.airspacemag.com/space/the-road-to-mars-961235/?page=3|title=The Road to Mars...|work=Air & Space Magazine|access-date=2018-07-19|language=en}}</ref> The lander had a tub-shaped [[lifting body]] with [[winglets]], and was one of the first detailed designs for Mars lander although it would not be able to fly in the revised figures for the Mars atmospheric conditions.<ref name="The Road to Mars"/> The Aeronutronic Mars lifting-body lander design was based on Mars atmosphere of mostly nitrogen about 10% of Earth.<ref name="The Road to Mars"/>
The July 1965 marked a shift away from lifting body and winged glider style Mars landers to ballistic entry gumdrop style landers.<ref>[http://spaceflighthistory.blogspot.com/2015/09/the-martian-adventure-gumdrops-on-mars.html]</ref>
In the 1970s the Mini-Sniffer aircraft were made in several versions so it could also operate in an all-{{chem|C|O|2}} environment.<ref name="nasa.gov"/> The Mini-Sniffer could run without oxygen by using [[hydrazine]], and the design was considered for sampling the atmosphere of Mars.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dfrc.nasa.gov/Gallery/Photo/Mini-Sniffer/index.html| title=NASA Dryden Mini-Sniffer Photo Collection| website=www.dfrc.nasa.gov| language=en|access-date=2018-01-21}}</ref> The airplane had a large propeller to be effective in the thin air and many flights of various configurations were made between 1975 and 1982.<ref name="dfrc.nasa.gov">{{Cite web | url=https://www.dfrc.nasa.gov/Gallery/Photo/Mini-Sniffer/index.html | title=NASA Dryden Mini-Sniffer Photo Collection}}</ref>
A winged rover design was proposed in the 1970s, to cover more area than the stationary ''Viking'' landers.<ref name=morton/> There was a proposal by NASA in the 1990s for a Mars airplane to fly on Mars by the anniversary of the Wright Brothers's first flight, in the "Faster, Better, Cheaper" era.<ref name=morton/> The [[Aerial Regional-scale Environmental Survey|ARES Mars airplane]] proposal was selected as a [[Mars Scout Program]] candidate, but not selected for flight.
In 2015, a Mars aircraft was considered as an option in the re-boot of the Japanese [[MELOS]] mission.<ref name="melos2015">[http://mepag.jpl.nasa.gov/meeting/2015-02/08_MEPAG_Miyamoto_Final.pdf]</ref> One early design proposed a wing-span of 1.2m, a mass of 2.1 kg, and with the following mission profile:<ref name=melos2015/> During the landing phase of the surface element of MELOS, the aircraft would be released at an altitude of 5 km then fly 4 minutes, covering 25 horizontal km.<ref name=melos2015/>
==Airplanes==
Prototype Mars planes have flown at close to 30 km (about 98 thousand feet) altitude on Earth (in roughly half of the average air pressure at Mars surface),<ref name=ame/> and tested expandable wings that cure in ultraviolet light.<ref>[http://www.engr.uky.edu/~idea /wiki/lib/exe/fetch.php?id%3Dpeople%253Ajel%253A00pubs%26cache%3Dcache%26media%3Dpublications:0503_ieee_simpson.pdf BIG BLUE: High-Altitude UAV Demonstrator of Mars Airplane Technology]</ref> For flight in Mars' atmosphere, the [[Reynolds number]] would be very low compared to flight in Earth's atmosphere.<ref name=uk1>[http://marsairplane.okstate.edu/files/papers/AIAA-2004-1373.pdf Development and Flight Testing of a UAV with Inflatable-Rigidizable Wings – University of Kentucky] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100617225204/http://marsairplane.okstate.edu/files/papers/AIAA-2004-1373.pdf |date=2010-06-17 }}</ref> [[Valles Marineris]] was targeted for an unmanned aircraft flight and by Mars' gliders.<ref name=john/><ref name=morton/>
Gliders could carry more scientific instrumentation, but cover less area.<ref name=morton/> Hydrazine has been proposed as a fuel for Mars aircraft.<ref name=morton/> At one point, NASA was developing plans for a wok-sized airplane "micromission", which would piggyback on a separate Mars bound payload.<ref name=morton/> Mach 1 on Mars can be about 240 meters per second (537 mph) while it is about 332 m/s (743 mph) on Earth.<ref name="nasa4">{{Cite web |url=http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/missions/profile.cfm?MCode=MarsSciLab |title=Mars Science Laboratory Mission Profile |access-date=2012-08-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110221113610/http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/missions/profile.cfm?MCode=MarsSciLab |archive-date=2011-02-21 |url-status=dead }}</ref>
The Daedalus proposal in the canceled Mars Scout program designed a Mars glider that would fly over 400 km along the [[Coprates Chasma]]<ref name="authorstream.com">{{Cite web | url=http://www.authorstream.com/Presentation/Reginaldo-44140-DaedalusPresentation-Mars-Scout-Mission-2011-Presentation-Outline-Team-Roles-Specializations-daedaluspresent-Education-ppt-powerpoint/ | title=Daedaluspresentation}}</ref>
[[File:ARES soaring over Mars.jpg|thumb|ARES concept]] Proposed Mars Airplane concepts include: *'''ARES''' ([[Aerial Regional-scale Environmental Survey]])<ref name="ares">Ares Mars Airplane [http://marsairplane.larc.nasa.gov/ website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100325205154/http://marsairplane.larc.nasa.gov/ |date=2010-03-25 }}</ref> *'''MAGE''' (Mars Airborne Geophysical Explorer)<ref name=john/> *'''AME''' (Airplane for Mars Exploration)<ref name=ame>[http://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/research/technology-onepagers/mars-airplane.html Mars Airplane – Ames Research Center]</ref> *'''MATADOR''' (Mars Advanced Technology Airplane for Deployment, Operations and Recovery)<ref name=ame/> *'''[[Sky-Sailor]]''', solar powered airplane with micro-robots<ref>[http://www.sky-sailor.ethz.ch/ Sky-Sailor]</ref> *'''Kitty Hawk''', multi-glider mission<ref name=john>[http://www.jmcgowan.com/marsplane.html John F. McGowan, Ph.D. – '''Wings on Mars''' (December 3, 1999)]</ref> *'''Daedalus''', glider with 400+ km range<ref>[http://soliton.ae.gatech.edu/people/rbraun/classes/spacesystems05/Proposals/DaedalusProposal.pdf Daedalus (April 2005)]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> (Mars Scout 2011 proposal)<ref name="authorstream.com"/> *'''ARMaDA''', "Advanced Reconnaissance Martian Deployable Aircraft"<ref name=esa1>[http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Human_Spaceflight/Exploration/Euroavia_students_design_Martian_aerial_vehicle Euroavia students design Martian aerial vehicle (ESA)]</ref> *'''MAREA''', "Martial Aerial Research Euroavia Airplane"<ref name=esa1/> *Prandtl-M<ref>[http://www.nasa.gov/centers/armstrong/features/mars_airplane.html Could This Become the First Mars Airplane? NASA June 2015]</ref> (Preliminary Research Aerodynamic Design to Land on Mars)<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.americaspace.com/2015/07/01/flying-the-friendly-martian-skies-nasa-to-test-mars-airplane-prototype/|title=Flying the Friendly Martian Skies: NASA to Test Mars Airplane Prototype|date=2015-07-01|work=AmericaSpace|access-date=2018-07-19|language=en-US}}</ref> *[[NASA Mini-Sniffer]], considered for sampling the atmosphere of Mars, tested running on hydrazine (air independent).<ref name="dfrc.nasa.gov"/>
==Balloons== Balloons may provide an alternative to parachutes, allowing for a soft landing.<ref name=bal>[http://mars.nasa.gov/programmissions/missions/missiontypes/balloons/ NASA – Mars Balloons]</ref> A balloon could allow a lander to take off and land at a new site.<ref name=bal/> Two types of balloon technology are super-pressure and Montgolfiere.<ref name=bal/> The super-pressure balloons try to contain the pressure caused by heating to maintain altitude.<ref name=bal/>
The Montgolfiere would use heated Martian air to create lift.<ref name=bal/> An example of concept for Mars balloon was the Mars Geoscience Aerobot.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://trs-new.jpl.nasa.gov/dspace/handle/2014/21938 |title=Mars Balloon Trajectory Model for Mars Geoscience Aerobot Development (1997) |access-date=2012-03-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222153053/http://trs-new.jpl.nasa.gov/dspace/handle/2014/21938 |archive-date=2014-02-22 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Some work has been done to develop extremely thin, flexible solar cells that could allow a balloon's skin itself to generate power from the Sun.<ref>http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/marsconcepts2012/pdf/4307.pdf</ref>
==Rotorcraft== [[File:PIA22460-Mars2020Mission-Helicopter-20180525.jpg|thumb|[[Mars Helicopter]]]] In 2002, a paper was published suggesting autonomous robotic helicopters for Mars exploration, possible for the [[Mars Scout Program]].<ref name="Young 1–378 vol.1">{{Cite book|last=Young|first=Larry|last2=Aiken|first2=E.W.|last3=Gulick|first3=Virginia|last4=Mancinelli|first4=Rocco|last5=Briggs|first5=Geoffrey|date=2002-02-01|title=Rotorcraft as Mars Scouts|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/3968849|volume=1|pages=1–378 vol.1|doi=10.1109/AERO.2002.1036856|isbn=978-0780372313}}</ref> A number of advantages of a viable rotorcraft design were noted, including the ability to pass over difficult Mars terrain yet still visit multiple sites ''in situ''.<ref name="Young 1–378 vol.1"/> The short hop made by Lunar [[Surveyor 6]] in 1967 was noted as example of hopping to visit another site.<ref name="Young 1–378 vol.1"/>
A small scout drone, launching from a Mars rover has been in development in the late 2010s, including US$23 million for a helicopter demonstration in 2018.<ref>[http://spacenews.com/nasa-mars-exploration-efforts-turn-to-operating-existing-missions-and-planning-sample-return/ NASA Mars exploration efforts turn to operating existing missions and planning sample return]. Jeff Foust, ''Space News''. 23 February 2018.</ref><ref>[https://spaceflightnow.com/2018/03/15/nasa-to-decide-soon-whether-flying-drone-will-launch-with-mars-2020-rover/ NASA to decide soon whether flying drone will launch with Mars 2020 rover]. Stephen Clarke, ''Spaceflight Now''. 15 March 2018.</ref> The program for the [[Mars Helicopter]] possibly for the [[Perseverance (rover)|''Perseverance'' rover]] would have a high resolution, downward-looking camera for navigation, landing, and science surveying of the terrain, and a communication system to relay data back to the rover.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www-robotics.jpl.nasa.gov/publications/Richard_Volpe/isairas%202014%20paper,%20volpe,%20v8.pdf |title=2014 Robotics Activities at JPL |last=Volpe |first=Richard |work=Jet Propulsion Laboratory |accessdate=1 September 2015}}</ref>
==Other aircraft and airborne devices== [[File:PIA19405-MarsInSightLander-Assembly-ParachuteTest-2015February.jpg|thumb|The Discovery Program's latest mission, Mars [[InSight]] lander, has its parachute tested]] [[File:Viking Aeroshell - GPN-2000-001903.jpg|[[Viking 1]] aeroshell|thumb]] [[File:Curiosity's_descent_in_high-definition.ogv|thumb|Video of descent stage coming in for a landing on Mars (2012, NASA)]] [[File:593484main pia14839 full Curiosity's Sky Crane Maneuver, Artist's Concept.jpg|thumb|Artistic depiction of MSL Curiosity Mars Rover being lowered from the ''Skycrane'']] *Mars rotorcraft<ref>[http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?AD=ADA480702 Young, et al. – Rotorcraft as Mars Scouts]</ref> *Hypersonic gliders were proposed by Wernher von Braun.<ref name=morton/> *Various parachutes have been the main air-borne device *Rocket-sustained flight as in the case of retro-rockets have also been a part of landing systems *Aeroshells from various spacecraft *A rocket powered hopper (e.g. [[Mars Geyser Hopper]]) *[[Mars Helicopter]] (MH), a mini-helicopter to scout routes for a rover<ref name='HMS approved'>[https://www.nasa.gov/press-release/mars-helicopter-to-fly-on-nasa-s-next-red-planet-rover-mission Mars Helicopter to Fly on NASA's Next Red Planet Rover Mission].Karen Northon, NASA News. 11 May 2018.</ref>
==Parachutes== [[File:HiRISE image of MSL during EDL (refined).png|thumb|left|Parachute of [[Mars Science Laboratory]] ([[Curiosity rover]]) descending on Gale crater]] {{clear}} [[File:Phoenix Lander seen from MRO during EDL2.jpg|thumb|left|Parachute of [[Phoenix (spacecraft)|Phoenix lander]] open as it descends in the Martian atmosphere. This picture was taken by the [[Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter]] with [[HiRISE]]]] {{clear}}
==Virtual== [[Mars Express]] HRSC and MRO's [[HiRISE]] data can provide virtual Mars flyovers by draping surface pictures over 3D terrain models.<ref>[http://www.planetary.org/blog/article/00002382/ TPS – Unbelievably spectacular flight through Candor ChasmaMar. 9, 2010]</ref><ref>[http://www.geoinf.fu-berlin.de/eng/projects/mars/highlight011-MawrthVallisAnimation.php Highlight of the Month January: Mawrth Vallis Animation (2012)]</ref><ref>[http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/video/index.php?id=792 Flyover Animation of Becquerel Crater on Mars]</ref>
